conclusion: To solve the problem, I will analyze the image to understand the flow paths of liquid through the baffles. By evaluating the connections and paths, I will determine which container (D or E) the liquid will ultimately flow into.

The image depicts a fluid flow system with liquid initially exiting from points labeled A, B, and C. These liquids then flow through a series of rectangular baffles before reaching two containers labeled D and E. The containers are positioned at the bottom of the image. The liquid paths form a network of channels that connect these points.

The problem requires identifying which container (D or E) the liquid will flow into after passing through the baffles. The image shows three initial liquid sources at points A, B, and C. From these points, the liquids flow through the baffles and into the containers.
Identify Pathways: First, observe the pathways created by the baffles. The liquids from A, B, and C must all flow through these channels.

Analyze Baffle Connections: Note how the channels from A, B, and C connect to the containers D and E. It is important to see whether there are any shared pathways or exclusive connections to either container.
Evaluate Path Intersections: Determine if any paths intersect or merge before reaching the containers. This will help establish which liquid ultimately ends up in each container.

premise: Based on the observed pathway connections, assign each liquid source to the container where it ultimately ends up.
conclusion: Upon analyzing the pathways, it becomes evident that the liquid originating from A will eventually flow into container D, while the liquid from B flows into container E. The liquid from C will follow the path leading to container D.

premise: Since the flow from A will go to D and the flow from B will go to E, the answer is D.
